title: How to Compose a Good Bassline

steps.headline: Find the roots of the chord on the bass instruments or write them out on a bass clef with the melody and chords.
Repeat.
steps.description: From this point, a punk bassline is almost automatically made by playing repetitively on these notes. To ensure a more interesting line though, it is first useful to smooth out the bassline.

steps.headline: To smooth out the bassline, use scales or small jumps to connect the chords together.
steps.description: Don't be afraid to invert the chords, or change what note in the chord is on the bottom, to make the line smooth.

steps.headline: Check the melody.
steps.description: See if it sounds independent of the bassline. Try to use contrary motion, such as when the melody goes up, then the bass goes down and vice versa.

steps.headline: At this point, this is a simple bassline.
steps.description: This may do for some, but the more creative will want to embellish.

steps.headline: Experiment with rhythms to get a groove going.
Take the other notes in the chord or tones close to the original note and play those once in a while.
steps.description: Be sure to focus on the main note though.

steps.headline: Let the bassline complement the other parts.
steps.description: If this has a riff, the bass would love to have its turn with it. Just don't make it a carbon copy of another part, or else the bassline should take the bus home!

steps.headline: Find out what chords your guitarist is playing.
Repeat those notes in time with the guitar.
steps.description: Keep experimenting until you are comfortable.

steps.headline: Using the notes you were already playing as a base, add different notes to create a melody.
steps.description: Keep experimenting until you find something that sounds good.

steps.headline: Take on board constructive criticism from your bandmates.
steps.description: It's very important that you work together and put in equal amounts of effort.

tyn: Manuscript paper (if knowledgeable of formal music)
Basic melody and chords (does not need to be final)
